I was very intrigued about the "no poop" thing, so I had to look for some information. It turns out they save it all inside until they die (complete life cycle about 14-16 days):

"They still need to poo, so it's been said that they 'explode' with waste at the end of their lives. However, that's "a bit of an over-exaggeration", says Thoemmes.

They do save it all up until death, though. When a Demodex dies, its body dries out and all the built-up waste degrades on your face.

"It's not an exploding action necessarily, but it's true that all their waste builds up over time and then there's one large flush of bacteria," says Thoemmes. "It's not just coming in discrete units over time, it's a lot built up that comes out."

Face mites have been implicated as cause of rosacea. Technically, it is the bacteria inside the mites. When they die, the bacteria migrate to the person's face irritating it and the result is the red acne-like bumps that appear on the face. Standard treatment now is to use an anti-bacterial called Metronidazole which is a topical gel and costs around $200 for a 45 grams! Talk about rip-offs! When my rosacea flares up I apply the gel and it goes away but never completely. Whether this is coincidental or if the gel is really helping I can't say. Never had rosacea until after my 64th birthday.
